It is not, therefore, at all out of keeping‚ although critics have taken exception to the poem on this ground, that Horace makes Alphius rhapsodise on the charms of a rural life, and having tried them, creep back within the year to his money- bags and his ten per cent. In the charming sketch presented in this poem of the peasant's life, it is easy to see that Horace is drawing from nature, like Burns in his more elaborate picture of the “ Cottar's Saturday Night.’' Horace had obviously watched closely the ways of the peasantry round his Apulian home, as he did at a later date those of the Sabine country, and to this we owe many of the most delightful passages in his works. He omits no oppor- tunity of contrasting their purity of morals‚ and the. austere sels-denial of their life, with the luxurious habits and reckless vice of the city life of Rome.
